etymologies: mid 16th century: alteration of dialect striddle, back-formation from dialect striddling ‘astride’, from stride + the adverbial suffix -ling

definitions: sit or stand with one leg on either side of

examples.text: he turned the chair around and straddled it

shortDefinitions: sit or stand with one leg on either side of

examples.text: he shifted his legs, straddling them to keep his balance

definitions: stand, walk, or sit with one's legs wide apart

examples.text: the colonel straddled in front of the fire

shortDefinitions: stand, walk, or sit with one's legs wide apart

definitions: extend across or be situated on both sides of

examples.text: a mountain range straddling the Franco-Swiss border

shortDefinitions: extend across or be situated on both sides of

synonyms.text: be situated on both sides of

definitions: take up or maintain an equivocal position with regard to (a political issue)

examples.text: a man who had straddled the issue of taxes

shortDefinitions: take up or maintain equivocal position with regard

definitions: an act of sitting or standing with one's legs wide apart

examples.text: a sideways-on stance such as a straddle

shortDefinitions: act of sitting or standing with one's legs wide apart

definitions: a simultaneous purchase of options to buy and to sell a security or commodity at a fixed price, allowing the purchaser to make a profit whether the price of the security or commodity goes up or down.
shortDefinitions: simultaneous purchase of options to buy and to sell security or commodity at fixed price
